about_page.lead: Karigar Foundation advances dignity, safety, and fair wages for workers through legal aid, awareness, and rapid support. We partner with communities, employers, and institutions to make rights real on the ground.

mission.title: Our Mission
mission.desc: Protect workers’ rights and improve livelihoods by providing timely legal assistance, awareness, healthcare access, and emergency relief.

vision.title: Our Vision
vision.desc: A society where every worker is valued, safe at work, and paid fairly—without fear or exploitation.

values.title: Our Values
items: Dignity
Justice
Transparency
Community
Speed & Care

whatWeDo.title: What We Do
items: Legal help for unpaid wages, harassment, and workplace exploitation.
Rights awareness workshops and helpline support.
Emergency assistance: medical care, rations, and temporary shelter.
Skill-building and referrals for safer, better jobs.

approach.title: How We Work
items: Listen first: document the case and immediate needs.
Resolve quickly: negotiate, escalate, or litigate where required.
Support the family: health, counseling, and cash/relief where needed.
Prevent repeat harm: train workers and engage responsible employers.

items.text: Scaling programs and partnerships across districts.

partners.title: Partners & Supporters
partners.desc: We work closely with government departments, hospitals, local NGOs, and responsible employers.

objectives.title: Trust Objectives
objectives.intro: Registered aims and activities the foundation undertakes for public welfare and worker upliftment.
items: Enroll workers as trust members and help obtain Labour Department identity cards.
Support children of workers in cases of poverty, accident, or death.
Fight workplace injustice against any worker and secure fair remedies.
Facilitate accident & health insurance and connect members to government welfare schemes.
Ensure fair valuation/payment of workers’ output; provide official certification where required.
Apply for and execute eligible government and private tenders in the trust’s remit.
Form self-help groups (SHGs), link with banks, enable credit, and provide skill training; market artisan and cottage-industry products via fairs and exhibitions.

Establish and operate institutions for social development: libraries, reading rooms, gyms, clinics, schools (primary to senior), colleges, technical/medical institutes, hostels, animal hospitals, gaushalas, cultural centres, cottage industry and vocational hubs, and agricultural science centres.
Run recognized education programs in remote/tribal/backward regions, including special schools for needy children, with proper governing bodies and committees.
Organize seminars, conventions, exhibitions, and competitions at regular intervals.
Recognize exemplary citizens—honest officials, employees, social workers, and public leaders—with certificates and awards.
Mobilize resources for trust programs via public donations and grants from district/state/central governments, ministries, and national/international agencies.
Assist the destitute and needy; provide low-interest microloans for self-employment.
Advance the upliftment of Dalits, OBCs, SC/ST communities, and indigenous groups.
Promote agriculture and horticulture: introduce appropriate technology, value-addition, and processing; guide and train for rural enterprises.
Provide disaster relief during floods, droughts, fires, pandemics, and other crises; coordinate with Social Welfare Boards, Health Departments, and allied agencies.
Offer training and facilities for rural crafts and trades—tailoring, knitting, embroidery, and allied skills.
Protect the environment through social/agro-forestry, biodiversity conservation, and afforestation.
Promote renewable energy sources and their adoption in communities.
Disseminate important cultural, scientific, economic, and social information; convene public workshops.
Conduct cultural programs—dance, drama, music—and operate training centres for the arts.
Undertake any activity that promotes public welfare and benefit.
Establish allied institutions to deliver specialized projects where necessary.
Provide training and rehabilitation for persons with disabilities; support government schemes for assistive devices and prosthetics.

Promote sustainable agriculture among small, marginal, and women farmers: composting/vermicomposting, NADEP, integrated pest management, and climate resilience—offering free capacity-building where feasible.
Raise awareness about the necessity of education—especially girls’ education and equal rights for women.
Promote ethical, moral, and social values through cultural events, talks, and exhibitions.
Implement health and family-welfare initiatives (immunization, screenings, and camps) under relevant ministries and schemes.
Operate old-age homes and de-addiction/tobacco control centres as per social policy and norms.
Raise awareness on communicable and chronic diseases (TB, HIV/AIDS, diabetes control, malaria, cancer, hepatitis, etc.) and provide free medical services to the poor where possible.
Support implementation of women & child development programs and schemes.
Collaborate with ministries/boards: Women & Child, Social Welfare (state & central), Handloom & Handicrafts, Textiles, Khadi, NABARD, Human Resource/Skill Development, UNICEF, etc.
Provide emergency relief in calamities such as droughts, floods, fires, and earthquakes.
Enable minorities, the helpless, persons with disabilities, and destitute students through public-interest welfare programs with government support.
Establish rural industries and training centres; create self-employment opportunities through technical skilling and SHG formation.
Educate farmers, laborers, and artisans on rural-industry technologies; spread awareness via street plays, films, and documentaries.
Offer free training in yoga, naturopathy, and sports for community health in rural areas.
Promote rural sanitation, safe drinking water, housing, and public health; spread information on low-cost housing schemes and related government support.
